Tabs Component

The Tabs component provides an accessible, responsive interface for displaying multiple related content sections. Perfect for code examples in different languages, platform-specific instructions, or any multi-view content.

Features

  • ✅ Accessible - Full ARIA support and keyboard navigation
  • ✅ Responsive - Works seamlessly on mobile and desktop
  • ✅ Keyboard Navigation - Arrow keys, Home, End support
  • ✅ Automatic IDs - Unique IDs generated automatically
  • ✅ Dark Mode - Automatic theme support
  • ✅ Lightweight - Pure JavaScript, no dependencies

Basic Usage

Create tabs with the `

console.log('Hello from JavaScript!');
print('Hello from Python!')
fmt.Println("Hello from Go!")

Syntax

The Tabs component uses JSX-like syntax:

<!--NEW_TABS_PLACEHOLDER_1-->

Each <Tab> requires a title attribute and supports full markdown content including code blocks, lists, images, and other components.

Code Examples

Tabs are perfect for showing the same functionality in different languages:

// Fetch API example
async function fetchData() {
  const response = await fetch('/api/data');
  const data = await response.json();
  return data;
}
# Requests library example
import requests

def fetch_data():
    response = requests.get('/api/data')
    return response.json()
// Fetch with types
interface DataResponse {
  id: number;
  name: string;
}

async function fetchData(): Promise<DataResponse> {
  const response = await fetch('/api/data');
  return await response.json();
}
// Using reqwest
use reqwest;
use serde_json::Value;

async fn fetch_data() -> Result<Value, reqwest::Error> {
    let response = reqwest::get("/api/data")
        .await?
        .json::<Value>()
        .await?;
    Ok(response)
}

Installation Instructions

Use tabs for package manager alternatives:

npm install chiron --save-dev
npm run build
yarn add chiron --dev
yarn build
pnpm add -D chiron
pnpm build

Configuration Examples

Show different configuration formats:

site:
  title: My Documentation
  description: Comprehensive docs
  baseUrl: https://docs.example.com

theme:
  name: metis
  primaryColor: '#007bff'
{
  "site": {
    "title": "My Documentation",
    "description": "Comprehensive docs",
    "baseUrl": "https://docs.example.com"
  },
  "theme": {
    "name": "metis",
    "primaryColor": "#007bff"
  }
}
[site]
title = "My Documentation"
description = "Comprehensive docs"
baseUrl = "https://docs.example.com"

[theme]
name = "metis"
primaryColor = "#007bff"

Platform-Specific Commands

# Windows PowerShell
$env:NODE_ENV="production"
npm run build

if ($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0) {
    Write-Host "Build successful!" -ForegroundColor Green
}
# macOS Terminal
export NODE_ENV=production
npm run build

if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "Build successful!"
fi
# Linux Bash
NODE_ENV=production npm run build

# Check exit status
[ $? -eq 0 ] && echo "Build successful!"

Framework Comparisons

Compare implementations across different frameworks:

import { useState } from 'react';

function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  return (
    <div>
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>
        Increment
      </button>
    </div>
  );
}
<template>
  <div>
    <p>Count: {{ count }}</p>
    <button @click="count++">
      Increment
    </button>
  </div>
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';
const count = ref(0);
</script>
<script>
  let count = 0;
</script>

<div>
  <p>Count: {count}</p>
  <button on:click={() => count++}>
    Increment
  </button>
</div>
import { Component } from '@angular/core';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-counter',
  template: `
    <div>
      <p>Count: {{ count }}</p>
      <button (click)="increment()">
        Increment
      </button>
    </div>
  `
})
export class CounterComponent {
  count = 0;
  
  increment() {
    this.count++;
  }
}

Perfect for documentation sites!

System Requirements

Component Minimum Recommended
Node.js 16.x 20.x or later
RAM 2GB 4GB+
Disk 500MB 1GB+

Make sure you have the latest LTS version.

Getting Help

  1. Check the documentation

Response time: Usually within 24 hours.

Accessibility

The Tabs component follows WCAG 2.1 Level AA guidelines:

Keyboard Navigation

Key Action
Arrow Right / Arrow Down Next tab
Arrow Left / Arrow Up Previous tab
Home First tab
End Last tab
Tab Move focus out
Enter / Space Activate focused tab

Screen Reader Support

  • Proper ARIA roles (tablist, tab, tabpanel)
  • aria-selected states
  • aria-controls and aria-labelledby relationships
  • tabindex management for keyboard navigation

Focus Management

  • Clear focus indicators on tab buttons
  • First tab receives focus by default
  • Focus follows activation

Component Props

The <Tab> component accepts the following prop:

Prop Type Required Description
title string Yes The tab button label

Technical Details

HTML Structure

The component generates semantic HTML:

<div class="tabs-container" data-tabs-id="tabs-1">
  <div class="tabs-header" role="tablist" aria-label="Content tabs">
    <button class="tab-button active" 
            role="tab" 
            aria-selected="true"
            aria-controls="tabs-1-panel-0"
            id="tabs-1-tab-0"
            tabindex="0">
      Tab Title
    </button>
  </div>
  <div class="tab-panel active" 
       role="tabpanel" 
       aria-labelledby="tabs-1-tab-0"
       id="tabs-1-panel-0">
    Content here
  </div>
</div>

Automatic ID Generation

Each tabs instance receives a unique ID (tabs-1, tabs-2, etc.) to ensure proper ARIA relationships even with multiple tab groups on the same page.

JavaScript Behavior

The tabs functionality is automatically loaded via base.js. The script:

  • Switches active tab on click
  • Handles keyboard navigation
  • Updates ARIA attributes dynamically
  • Manages focus state

Best Practices

Do's ✅

  • Limit tab count - Keep to 3-6 tabs for best UX
  • Similar content length - Tabs should have comparable amounts of content
  • Clear labels - Use short, descriptive tab titles (1-3 words)
  • Logical order - Arrange tabs by popularity or workflow
  • Test keyboard nav - Ensure all tabs are accessible via keyboard

Don'ts ❌

  • Don't nest tabs - Avoid tabs inside tabs (use sections instead)
  • Don't hide critical info - Important content should be visible by default
  • Don't use for navigation - Use menus/links for site navigation
  • Don't overload content - Very long content should use separate pages
  • Don't forget mobile - Test horizontal scrolling on small screens

When to Use Tabs

Good Use Cases ✅

  • Code examples in multiple languages
  • Package manager installation instructions (npm, yarn, pnpm)
  • Configuration format alternatives (YAML, JSON, TOML)
  • Platform-specific commands (Windows, macOS, Linux)
  • Framework comparisons (React, Vue, Svelte)
  • Before/after examples
  • API response formats (JSON, XML, CSV)

Alternatives ❌

  • Long-form content → Use Accordion instead
  • Sequential steps → Use numbered lists or step-by-step guide
  • Single content item → No need for tabs
  • Critical information → Make it visible by default
  • Site navigation → Use navigation menu

Styling

The component integrates with Chiron's design system:

  • CSS Variables - Uses theme colors automatically
  • Dark Mode - Switches colors based on theme
  • Responsive - Mobile-first design with horizontal scroll
  • Customizable - Override styles via custom CSS

CSS Classes

  • .tabs-container - Main wrapper
  • .tabs-header - Tab buttons container
  • .tab-button - Individual tab button
  • .tab-button.active - Active tab button
  • .tab-panel - Content panel
  • .tab-panel.active - Visible content panel

Browser Support

  • ✅ Chrome 90+
  • ✅ Firefox 88+
  • ✅ Safari 14+
  • ✅ Edge 90+
  • ✅ Mobile browsers (iOS Safari, Chrome Mobile)

Performance

  • No external dependencies - Pure JavaScript
  • Lazy content - Only active tab content is visible
  • Minimal CSS - ~50 lines of styles
  • Fast rendering - No framework overhead

Examples in Documentation

Tabs are used throughout this documentation:

  • Getting Started - Installation instructions
  • API Reference - Code examples
  • Configuration - Config formats
  • Full demo at Tabs Demo

Related Components

  • Accordion - For collapsible sections
  • Callout - For highlighting information
  • Button - For call-to-action elements
